ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MINI TURF CLUB ACTIVITIES


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he is aware that innocent persons found in food stalls in Housing and Development Board

Column: 1608

estates in the afternoons of race days are being arrested and taken to Police stations and detained till the evening, and, if so, if he will explain why this is being done.

    The Minister of State for Law and Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering this question on behalf of my Minister.

Column: 1609



    A serious problem which exists in HDB estates is that of illegal bookmaking and betting taking place during the afternoons of race days while races are in progress. Commonly known as "mini turf club activities", these have become blatant and widespread. On race days large groups of persons, sometimes as many as a hundred or more, congregate at various locations such as hawker centres, coffee shops, shophouses or void decks in HDB estates, to place bets on the results of horse races.

    In 1981 alone, the police received a total of 8,887 '999' calls complaining about such gambling activities. At least 2,400 of these calls or about 50 per race day referred directly to these mini turf club activities. In addition, the eight Police Land Divisions and the CID also received 405 such complaints. The undesirable activities of the mini turf clubs have also been widely discussed in the press, and I recall that last week Members also referred to this matter in this House. Secret society and other criminal activities are also associated with this illegal gambling.

    To deal with this problem which causes annoyance and apprehension to the residents in the HDB estates, the police conduct raids at locations where such activities take place. In 1981 alone, a total of 2,372 raids were conducted, resulting in the arrest of over 2,600 persons.

    Persons arrested during these raids are brought back to the police station together with whatever evidence that is seized during the raids. The arrested persons have to be questioned, statements have to be recorded and evidence has to be processed before a decision is taken to prosecute. When a large number of persons are arrested, this may take several hours. Those who cannot be prosecuted due to lack of evidence are released the same afternoon or evening.

    I can assure hon. Members that there has not been any indiscriminate arrest of persons by the police in these raids. Before every raid the police carry out careful surveillance to identify the culprits before moving in to arrest them. The police has to-date received no official complaint of any specific case of wrongful arrest.

Column: 1610



    As a lawyer, the hon. Member for Anson must know that it is not easy to bring about a successful prosecution of persons under the various provisions of our Betting Act. Sufficient evidence of the placing of bets must be adduced before you can get a conviction. To make it difficult for the police to prove gambling, bookmakers have resorted to keeping track of bets by using coloured chips, water-melon seeds, Chinese chess counters, buttons, bottle caps, match sticks and all sorts of other ingenious devices. Thus, those persons who are released and not prosecuted due to insufficient evidence cannot be said to be innocent bystanders.

    Continuing action by the police is necessary, Mr Speaker, if we are to combat this problem. The Member for Anson may be interested to know that a total of 31 public complaints of such illegal gambling activities were made by persons residing in Anson constituency. Instead of supporting the action of the police in stamping out gambling, the hon. Member for Anson has preferred to recite the viewpoint of the illegal bookies. It is they who will swell their takings if police action is inhibited by distortions of the truth put forward by the Member for Anson.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I assure the Minister and the Members that I have not been approached by an illegal bookie.

     An hon. Member: Not yet.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: The man who saw me about this is a man who was innocently having a bowl of mee at the Henderson market at about 5 o'clock one afternoon on a Saturday. He was suddenly trundled off to the police station at Queenstown where he was kept until 6.30 p.m.

     Mr Speaker: Can you ask your supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: All I want to say is that whilst I appreciate the need to stamp out any illegal bookmaking, would the police take steps to ensure that innocent persons who are not there for bookmaking or betting are not suddenly trundled off to the police station? This man told me that the only questions asked were, "How many fathers and mothers have you got here?" And then he was released at 6.30 p.m.

Column: 1611



     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have listened to the hon. Member for Anson. I have answered the question fully. He persists in maintaining . . . now it is not "persons" in the plural but an innocent "person" in the singular . . . if he maintains that innocent persons or an innocent person has been harassed or wrongfully arrested, then if he sincerely believes in this, the question is, why has he not made a written complaint to the Ministry of Home Affairs or to the police, giving particulars as to who, when, where, location and time, so that this can be investigated? And we will investigate. Not to have made any written complaint but to have raised a general question, thereby raising the spectre of innocent persons being trundled off, gives the impression to this House, to me, and certainly to members of the public, that here we are not really hearing a case of a genuine accusation or complaint against the police but just to score a debating or publicity point.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If you want the name, I will give it to you.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Computerization)


    2. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board has commenced its computerization programme, and, if so, what are its priority areas to improve efficiency through computerization, particularly in view of its shortage of manpower and the fact that it has the greatest degree of exposure to the public.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister. The HDB embarked on its computerization programme in the early 1970s. At that time computerization focussed on financial operations because of the big volume of accounts involved. The main areas of application included:

    (a) accounting system for rental and purchase instalment payments of HDB flats;

Column: 1612



    (b) direct transfer of CPF monthly instalments and other payments from CPF Board to HDB for purchase of HDB flats;

    (c) direct payment of instalments, rent and service charges through the GIRO system operated by POSB and private banks;

    (d) monthly and daily-rated employee payroll; and

    (e) office inventory control.

Computerisation has enabled the HDB to provide better and faster services.

    In the late 1970s, computerization was extended to cover other applications, such as data processing and statistical analysis of research studies involving large volumes of data for administration and planning purposes, and engineering and surveying projects.

    HDB recently purchased a special computer for drafting engineering and architectural drawings. This will relieve the shortage of professional and technical manpower by improving staff productivity.

    HDB plans to acquire a more advanced computer to provide on-line services in areas such as payment, enquiry, application and allocation of premises. It will also study ways to maximize usage of computers to obtain better building design, control and management.

THOMSON CORRIDOR
(Measures to improve traffic flow)


    3. Dr Chau Sik Ting asked the Minister for National Development what further steps can be immediately taken to improve the traffic situation along Thomson Road between MacRitchie Reservoir and Moulmein Road which has deteriorated, pending the completion of the Sembawang Expressway.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, Thomson Road provides the only access for the northern part of the island to the city. The traffic volume along the northern corridor has been increasing steadily due to HDB's building developments in the

Column: 1613

north. The ultimate solution to traffic congestion along Thomson Road is the completion of the Sembawang/Central Expressway which will run from Avenue 1 Ang Mo Kio to Thomson Road. Construction is now in progress and the expressway is expected to be completed by the end of 1984.

    Pending the completion of the Sembawang/Central Expressway, the PWD has implemented a number of traffic management measures, such as the banning of right-turning movement from Thomson Road into Moulmein Road at their junctions to give more green time for city-bound traffic along Thomson Road. This has increased the city-bound traffic volume during the morning peak hours.

    An extra lane is also under construction for Upper Thomson Road in the direction of Lornie Road at the junction of Upper Thomson Road/Thomson Road/Lornie Road. There are also plans to ban right-turning from Lornie Road to Thomson Road at their junctions during the morning peak hours.

    The Department will continue to monitor the traffic situation along Thomson Road and, if necessary, adjustments to the green time of the traffic signals will be made.

INQUIRY UNDER SECTION 14 OF THE EMPLOYMENT ACT


(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Minister for Labour)

2.38 p.m.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, on 19th March 1982 at Question Time, the Member for Anson asked me a supplementary question, following my reply to Question No. 2 on the Order Paper. His question was whether I was aware of a case in the Court of Appeal where the Court held that there need be no enquiry held before a worker is dismissed and whether I would consider taking steps to amend the legislation to put that right. I presume he was then referring to the case of Lim Tow Peng and Another vs the Singapore Bus Services Limited, as reported in 1976 in Vol. 1, Malayan Law Journals at page 254. I have had the oppor-

Column: 1614

tunity since last Friday, Sir, to obtain and read the Judgment of the Court of Appeal. The Court held, and I quote the following passage at page 257, Column 2, from the Judgment of the Court:

    'In our judgment the provisions of section 14 are not mandatory. An employer is not obliged to comply with section 14 but if he disregards section 14 and dismisses an employee without an enquiry, as in this case, the dismissal can be enquired into and reinstatement with full pay ordered by the Minister whose decision cannot be challenged in any court. The effect of section 14 is that a dismissal without notice before due enquiry is wrongful and not that it is ineffective or null and void.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am only a layman when it comes to legal matters. But the Judgment seems to be clear enough. It is not necessary for an employer to hold an inquiry under section 14 of the Employment Act, but where an employee is dismissed without notice before due inquiry, the dismissal is wrongful and the employee has the right to present a complaint to the Minister who has the power to direct the employer to reinstate the employee. Any employer who fails to comply with the Minister's order of reinstatement will be guilty of an offence under the Act.

    Perhaps the Member for Anson can explain why he misled me and the House when he asked me to consider making an amendment to this section of the Act, when it is clear from the Judgment that no such amendment is necessary.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the point of my question to the Hon. Minister was this: that section 14 says "an employer may dismiss an employee after holding an inquiry." I thought the whole intention of the legislature was that there should be an inquiry before the employer dismissed an employee. But the Court of Appeal said in their Judgment that section 14 did not make it obligatory for the employer to hold an inquiry before he dismissed the employee. And my question to the Hon. Minister was this: would he consider amending that section to make it obligatory for an employer to hold an inquiry before he dismisses the employee?

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I thought I have quoted the Judgment in clear plain English. There is no need for an

Column: 1615

amendment to section 14 of the Employment Act. There is provision in the Act where an employee who is dismissed without due inquiry can seek redress from the Minister. And if the Minister after investigation found that it is true, he could order a reinstatement.

    I am not sure which part of the Employment Act that the Member for Anson thought that it was inadequate in this respect. Perhaps he could tell the House the nature of the amendment that he has in mind. If he has difficulty with section 14, I have a copy of the Act here to help him.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of the provision. The Hon. Minister will find it in section 14 (1). Here it is:

    'An employer may after due inquiry dismiss without notice an employee . . .'

It is that that I was talking about and I thought that the intention of the legislature was to require employers to hold an inquiry before they dismiss an employee without due notice. Now that the Court of Appeal has said that it is not obligatory for an employer to hold an inquiry, I want to know whether the Hon. Minister would consider amending this section to make it obligatory for an employer to hold an inquiry before he dismisses an employee without due notice.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: Sir, the answer is no, it is not necessary. The Member for Anson, in fact, has misled his client by advising him to refer the matter to the court which has no power to order a reinstatement. If he had advised his client correctly by referring the matter to the Ministry of Labour, the Ministry of Labour after due inquiry and investigation could make an order of reinstatement free of charge without having to refer it to the court.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, with all due respect, I think the Hon. Minister has missed my point. I am talking about the inquiry before dismissal. I am saying that it should be made mandatory for an inquiry before dismissal, before the employer dismisses the employee. I think we must try and keep this clear. I am talking of an

Column: 1616

inquiry conducted by the employer before dismissal.

     Mr Speaker: I thought the Minister said no.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong: I have already said no, it is not necessary.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: All right.

     Dr Ow Chin Hock (Leng Kee): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head J be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead JA-01 of the Main Estimates.*

    In moving this amendment, I would first like to ask the Minister about the progress of certain projects and activities under the Ministry, just like asking an old friend how he has been getting On in the past 15 months. First, a few specific questions:

    (i) What is the present status of the proposed Singapore History Gallery in the National Museum?

    (ii) What is the total amount of the Cultural Foundation at the latest convenient date; what is the amount of donations received last year; how much has been spent, and on what projects?

    (iii) Whether the Minister is satisfied with the progress made in the promotion of cultural activities by his cultural section in the year 1981?

    Next, on a more general point. Knowing the Minister is very receptive to ideas, may I take the opportunity to suggest that the Ministry of Culture come up with an over-all cultural development plan for the next 5-10 years. The plan should include several aspects:-

    (a) Cultural Infrastructure

    I am aware that there are several buildings for the Arts, such as National Theatre, Victoria Memorial Hall, Singapore Conference Hall and the Kallang Theatre. However, in my view, we still need to proceed with the proposed Cultural Complex in the Marina Centre. The Complex would provide the focal point of all our cultural activities.

    (b) More importantly, the cultural development plan should include various

Column: 1618

schemes to increase the so-called "demand" for cultural activities, such as inculcating an appreciation of the fine arts and reading habit among our people, particularly among our youngsters. From my experience, I notice that the people who go round visiting visual art exhibitions or attending concerts are generally from the same group. Efforts should be made to cultivate an interest in the arts among a wider spectrum of the population.

    (c) There should be a long-term plan in the training of our local artists. We should provide opportunities and avenues in selected areas of the arts for our local artists to become professionals.

    I believe the Minister is aware of the Report by Neil S. Duncan, who was in Singapore from March to May 1980 to undertake a study under the sponsorship of UNESCO. The Report made many recommendations, some good, some bad, some irrelevant. Many of these recommendations and the views contained in the Report are not original. In fact, they are the views and suggestions of the officials of the Ministry of Culture, National Theatre, People's Association and many local artists who were interviewed by Mr Duncan. However, in spite of this, the Report can still form the basis for a discussion with a view to developing it into a more comprehensive and cohesive cultural development plan. As a matter of fact, I had begun work on this but I was transferred out. Another aspect which the Ministry should look into is the cross-fertilization of cultures of the various ethnic groups. It is an extremely difficult task but nevertheless important. To begin with, the Ministry may want to look into the proposal of a systematic introduction and explanation of the customs and traditions of the various ethnic groups, through TV, radio and publications.

    The third point I would like to raise concerns the Information Officers Scheme. It was implemented in June 1980 and there were 64 posts provided, including some 15 Public Relations Officers who will be posted out to other Ministries. May I know

from the Minister the progress of this scheme? Has the Ministry overcome the recruitment problem by now? In my view, a successful Information Officer must not only be good in public relations but he must also be well-informed of the policies of the Ministry or department he is attached to.

    In this context, may I bring up the issue of the relationship between the press and the Government? Since the newspapers and the mass media have a crucial role to play in informing and explaining Government policies and policy changes to the people, at the same time reflecting the views and reactions from the people, there should be closer co-operation between the mass media and the Government. To achieve this, the journalists themselves must, in the first place, be well-informed of the policies, policy changes and their background and rationale. Of course, sensitive areas such as national security and tax changes should not be touched on. On the other hand, journalists must be worthy of the trust and confidence the Ministry is placing on them. Newspapers must use their discretion and judgment on what to print and what not to print. I need not have to remind our local journalists that they are first and foremost Singaporeans, and secondly journalists.

    Sir, our more established newspapers are generally responsible as they are able to place our national interest first. However, I am concerned about some of our younger journalists. Because of their educational background, they may be inspired by the Western newspapers and may want to imitate their Western counterparts. I hope these younger journalists are conscious that the political, economic, cultural background and social attitudes of our country are radically different from those in the West, and should not attempt to play the same game in the wrong court.

     Mr Tan Soo Khoon (Alexandra): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to be able to stand up once again in this House to say a few words of praise for the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation. Indeed, Sir, those who had reservations about whether out Radio and TV service would do well after its incorporation as a statutory board will no doubt agree that it has certainly done well. Minister by the Film and Publication Review Board. As hon. Members are aware, this Board was set up last year to draw up a new set of censorship guidelines for various media, like films, video tapes, books and magazines.

    Sir, censorship has been a hot topic in this House for many years. I shall not go into details as these have been reviewed all too often, except to say that many times it has been pointed out that our censorship rules are out of touch with reality in some aspects. Again, Sir, before the Hon. Minister jumps to the wrong conclusion about my likes and dislikes, as he did last year, let me point out that while many of us here are in favour of some liberalization of the present rigid rules, I am sure he will agree with me when I say that this has to be done within a proper framework of an acceptable level of morality, and that whatever changes we make will not result in the erosion of our traditional Asian values.

    My question is when can this report be made public, whether the Hon. Minister is prepared to give us some preliminary details today? Not only are we keen to know what will be revealed in the report but we will also be interested to know what can be made more revealing for Singaporeans.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Culture (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I take the points raised by the Member for Leng Kee first. He asked about the progress of the History of Singapore Gallery. This Gallery will comprise two parts. One will be a gallery that will present, through three dimensional displays of historical artifacts and materials, Singapore's early history and try to bring alive and make vivid for Singaporeans the scenes and people of early Singapore. The second part will be an audio visual presentation of the history of Singapore.

    The object of the History of Singapore Gallery is to provide Singaporeans, especially the young Singaporeans, with a sense of history and also to inspire Singaporeans with a recreation and recounting of the stories and accounts of the early pioneers of Singapore and the achievements of our founding fathers.

    The establishment of the Gallery requires the following work to be carried out. Firstly, renovation of the physical facilities for the permanent display of exhibits. Together with the planning of

Column: 1622

physical space, of course, research has got to be done to collect and document exhibits, artifacts, paintings, photographs, maps and so on. This is now in hand.

    Secondly, the audio visual presentation. For the audio visual presentation, the Ministry is now negotiating with a consultancy firm to undertake the project. This audio visual presentation will be a 20minute presentation which will augment the exhibits in the Gallery. It will depict three episodes; the first episode being the landing of Raffles and the early inhabitants of Singapore. The second episode will depict the life of the early and later immigrants up to World War 11, the Japanese Occupation Period and the Surrender. The third episode will depict the Post-war years leading to Singapore's self-government, independence through Malaysia, and present-day Singapore.

    The planning for the Gallery has already commenced. Detailed plans and drawings and cost estimates are being prepared by the Public Works Department. Renovation work will begin as soon as these are finalized and estimates approved.

    The second point that the Member raised was on the Cultural Foundation. He asked for the amounts collected in 1981. As at the end of 1980 the Cultural Foundation had a total of $2.7 million in its capital account, in the form of donations received. During the year 1981 the Foundation received a further $850,000 from donations as well as fund-raising projects. Therefore, the total capital amounts to $3.5 million. Of course, this capital has been earning interest. So the total in the Fund now is $4.3 million.

    In 1981 the Foundation approved 19 grants/schemes for cultural organizations and talented individuals, and these schemes will cost about $1 million. A total of $166,000 has been spent and outstanding commitments on these schemes amount to $872,000 which will be spent over the next two to three years.
